block.p: ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. This 333,500-square-foot, seven-floor, 120-foot-high exhibition and research center includes the new Hayden Planetarium, the Cullman Hall of the Universe and the Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth. The Hayden Planetarium contains the Space Theater, presenting ''Passport to the Universe,'' and the Big Bang Theater, featuring narrated visual and audio effects simulating the beginning of the universe. ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' with Mark Whitfield Quartet, at 6 to 8 p.m., with cash bar and tapas food. ''Full Moon: Apollo Mission Photographs of the Lunar Landscape,'' from NASA's Apollo missions to the moon; through January. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays to 8:45 p.m. Space shows run throughout the day. Admission (suggested donation) to the American Museum of Natural History, which includes the Rose Center: $10; for students and the elderly, $7.50; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. Admission to the museum, the Rose Center and the Hayden Planetarium space show: $19; students and the elderly, $14; children 12 and under, $11.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100. Reservations: (212) 769-5200.

HISTORIC RICHMONDTOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown. More than 25 buildings from the late 17th century to the 19th century, restored and furnished. This village and outdoor museum depict the history of Staten Island and the surrounding region. The exhibition ''Toys!'' will run through December 2001. Guided tours are available. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 p.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; the elderly, children 6 to 18 and students, $2.50; 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 351-1611.

INTREPID SEA-AIR-SPACE MUSEUM, Pier 86, West 46th Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. The Intrepid is a converted World War II aircraft carrier with two full decks of displays, including four theme halls: United States Navy Hall, Pioneer Hall, Technologies Hall and Intrepid Hall. ''Prepare to Dive: The 100th Anniversary of the Navy's First Submarine,'' an exhibition about the pioneering days of the submarine. ''Mission Control: From the Space Race to the Space Shuttle,'' an interactive exhibition exploring the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo projects and the current shuttle program. ''Korea: The Forgotten War, Remembered,'' on view through September 2001. Admission: $12; the elderly, veterans, reservists and ages 12 to 17, $9; ages 6 to 11, $6; ages 2 to 5, $2; under 2, free; wheelchair patrons, half price. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Information: (212) 245-0072.

LOWER EAST SIDE TENEMENT MUSEUM, 90 Orchard Street, at Broome Street. A look at the urban immigrant experience. The museum includes a partly restored tenement at 97 Orchard Street. Children can explore an apartment that was once home to the Confino family and interact with an actor playing a 13-year-old family member, Saturdays and Sundays at noon and at 1, 2 and 3 p.m. In another apartment visitors can experience the Jewish rite of mourning, sitting shiva with the Rogarshevsky family. These and the museum's two other apartments, which housed the Gumpertz and Baldizzi families, can be viewed on guided tours. Admission: $8 adults; $6 students and the elderly. Guided tours: Tuesdays through Fridays, every half-hour from 1 to 4 p.m.; Thursdays at 6 and 7 p.m., through Oct.; Saturdays and Sundays, every half-hour beginning at 11 a.m. until the last tour at 4:30 p.m. Tour prices: $9; students, the elderly and children over 5, $7; children 5 and under, free. Special prices for two and three tours. Information: (212) 431-0233.

SOUTH STREET SEAPORT MUSEUM AND MARKETPLACE, South and Fulton Streets, Lower Manhattan. In a 19th-century port district with restaurants, shops and bars, the museum has three galleries, a children's crafts center and a boat-building center. ''The Alan Villiers Collection: The Last of the Tall Ships,'' a photography exhibition. ''Prints From the Herman Melville Collection''; through Nov. 5. Museum hours: daily, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; until 8 p.m. Tuesday. Stores in the marketplace: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Sundays, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Museum admission: $6; the elderly, $5; students, $4; children 12 and under, $3. Information: (212) 748-8600; reservations for special events: (212) 748-8786; the marketplace, (212) 732-7678.

WORLD FINANCIAL CENTER, World Financial Center Courtyard Gallery, 200 Liberty Street, between West Street and Vesey Street, Lower Manhattan. Performances in and around the plaza. Sunday at noon, 1:30 and 3 p.m., Liberty Plaza Park, Inhabitations, performance arts troupe. Tomorrow and Sunday at 4 p.m., outside in the Winter Garden, ''The All-Clown Circus.'' Free. Information: (212) 945-0505.
RECREATION

''FIFTH AVENUE MILE,'' Manhattan. A one-mile run, beginning at Fifth Avenue and 80th Street. Tomorrow from 10:20 a.m. to 2 p.m. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. Advance registration fee, $17; $12 for club members; $10 junior and senior club members. Race-day registration, $22; $15 for club members; $13 for junior and senior club members. Information: (212) 423-2284.

''POLO SPORT RACE TO DELIVER,'' Central Park. A four-mile walk or run that starts and finishes on 72nd Street Transverse at Bethesda Fountain in Central Park. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club to benefit God's Love We Deliver, an organization that provides hot meals for people living with AIDS. Sunday at 10 a.m. A ''Kids Race'' for children 2 to 14 begins at 9 a.m. Advance registration fee for ''Race to Deliver,'' $17; $12 members; $10 for junior and senior club members. Race-day registration, $22; $15 for club members; $12 for junior and senior club members. Registration fee for the ''Kids Race,'' $6; $4 for club members. Information: (888) 235-RACE.

''MUSIC THAT HEALS: THIRD 5K RUN AND PEE WEE RUN,'' Prospect Park, Brooklyn. A five-kilometer run that starts and finishes at Bartel Pritchard Square, 15th Street and Prospect Park West. Proceeds benefit Music That Heals, a fund that provides for musical performances for seriously ill children. Sunday at 10 a.m. Advance registration fee, $10; $5 for the pee wee run. Race-day registration, $15; $5 for the pee wee run. Information: (718) 256-2268.

''SELF MAGAZINE'S WORKOUT IN THE PARK,'' Central Park, midpark at 72nd Street. With rock climbing, yoga, spinning and swing dancing, as well as instruction in meditation and a fashion show. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 3 p.m.; Rain date: Sunday. Tickets, $5 in advance; $10 on the day. Proceeds benefit the Big Bam! Foundation, an organization that promotes breast cancer awareness in young women. Information: (888) 844-7353.

''MS BIKE TOUR,'' Lower Manhattan, World Trade Center Plaza at Church Street between Liberty and Vesey Streets. Tours from 30 to 100 miles that begin and end at the World Trade Center; the 100-mile ride travels as far north as Rockland County. Sunday at 7:30 a.m. Advance registration fee, $20 until noon today. Race-day registration, $30 plus required pledges of $50 for the 30-mile race, $75 for the 60-mile race and $100 for the 100-mile race. Sponsored by the New York City Chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. Registration and information: (212) 463-9791.

''JUVENILE DIABETES WALK-A-THON,'' Battery Park, Lower Manhattan. A 12-kilometer walk from Battery Park City over the Brooklyn Bridge to the Brooklyn Heights Promenade and back. Sunday at 10 a.m. Sponsored by the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation. Information: (212) 785-9500.
ON THE STREET

74TH FEAST OF SAN GENNARO, Mulberry Street, between Canal and Houston Streets, and Hester and Grand Streets, between Baxter and Mott Streets, Little Italy. Today through Sunday. Hours: 11 a.m. to midnight; Sunday until 11 p.m. Information: (212) 768-9320.
WALL STREET COMMUNITY DAY, Wall Street, from South to Water Streets, Lower Manhattan. Featuring food, arts, crafts and antiques. Sponsored by Community Board No. 1. Today, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.
LOUIS VUITTON CLASSIC, Rockefeller Center. Fifty vintage vehicles, from Maseratis to motorcycles, will be on display. Today and tomorrow, 9 a.m. to 10 p.m.; Sunday, 9 a.m. to 4 p.m.
GREAT IRISH FAIR, Avenue of the Americas, from 43rd to 56th Streets. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the New York Chapter of the Ancient Order of Hibernians.
ARTS AND CRAFTS FAIR, West Side Community Garden, 89th and 90th Streets, west of Columbus Avenue. Tomorrow and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.
COOPER SQUARE COMMUNITY STREET FAIR, East Village, Third Avenue between Sixth and 14th Streets. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Cooper Square Community Development Committee.
ST. MARK'S CHURCH STREET FAIR, East 11th Street, between Second and Third Avenues, East Village. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by St. Mark's Church in the Bowery.
BLOCK 19 STREET FAIR, 19th Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, Chelsea. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.

ROCKAWAY MUSIC AND ARTS FALL FESTIVAL, Jacob Riis Park, Gateway National Recreation Area, Rockaway Beach, Queens. Includes arts and crafts, a petting zoo and pony rides for children, music and a flower show. Tomorrow and Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Free. Sponsored by the Rockaway Music and Arts Council.

ATLANTIC ANTIC STREET FESTIVAL, Atlantic Avenue, from Fourth Avenue to the waterfront, Brooklyn. With entertainment, food, fashion, antiques and furniture. Sunday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Presented by the Atlantic Avenue Local Development Corporation. Information: (718) 875-8993.

14th ANNUAL BROADWAY FLEA MARKET AND GRAND AUCTION, Shubert Alley and 44th Street, between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. Features theatrical memorabilia like playbills and autographed posters as well as tickets to Broadway shows and appearances by performers. Proceeds benefit Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS. Sunday, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m.; a grand auction of theater tickets and walk-on roles in theater and television, begins at 4:30 p.m.
TUDOR CITY FESTIVAL, Second Avenue from 43rd to 53rd Streets, Manhattan. With international food, arts, crafts and antiques. Sponsored by the Tudor City Association Inc., Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.

''TASTE-OF-THE-Y'' STREET FESTIVAL, Lexington Avenue, from 79th to 94th Streets. An outdoor sampling of the 92nd Street Y's programs, with music, arts and crafts demonstrations, storytelling and dance lessons. Other events include a performance by cast members of the Broadway revue ''Swing'' at 12:15 p.m. and the ''$92,000 Basketball Shoot-Out'' at 3 p.m. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Free. Information: (212) 996-1100
WALKING TOURS

''ROOSEVELT ISLAND'' visits the neighborhood and its landmarks. Meets today at 10:45 a.m. at the Roosevelt Island tramway at Second Avenue and 59th Street, upstairs at the token booth. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $10 plus $3 tram fare; $8 for students, the elderly and Society members. Information: (212) 935-3960.

HUDSON RIVER TO SOUTH FERRY. A hike of about three and one-half miles along the Hudson River from 23rd Street to the World Financial Center. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the Hudson River and 23rd Street. Fee: $3. Sponsored by the Outdoors Club. Information: (212) 877-0743.

''IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN BROOKLYN . . . CIRCA 1860'' tours religious and residential buildings of Brooklyn Heights including those designed by by Gamaliel King, Minard Lafever and Richard Upjohn. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the southwest corner of Court and Montague streets. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $15; $12 for members of the society or the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''FORDHAM ROAD TO POE COTTAGE'' explores the Fordham Road neighborhood in the Bronx. Meets tomorrow at 10 a.m. in front of the Edgar Allan Poe Cottage at Grand Concourse and East Kingsbridge Road. Sponsored by the Bronx County Historical Society. Fee: $10; society members, $5. Information: (718) 881-8900.

''FALL FLOWERS AND TREES IN CENTRAL PARK.'' Stops include the Shakespeare Garden, Hernshead and Strawberry Fields. Meets tomorrow at 8:30 a.m. at the 72nd Street Central Park West entrance to the park. Sponsored by the American Museum of Natural History. Fee: $15. Information and reservations: (212) 769-5200.

''HIKE NEW YORK CITY,'' a six- to eight-mile hike of Manhattan, Midtown and Downtown, with commentary on its history and folklore. Meets Sunday at 10 a.m. at the visitors' entrance to the United Nations, First Avenue and 45th Street. Fee: $25 plus refreshments. Led by Michael Kaback. Information: (212) 370-4214.

KEW GARDENS, Queens. An exploration of one of the city's garden communities. Meets tomorrow at 9:30 a.m. at the Queens Historical Society, 143-35 37th Avenue, Flushing. Led by Barry Lewis, whose tours have been broadcast on PBS. Those wishing to meet the tour in Kew Gardens should call for information. Sponsored by the Queens Historical Society and the Voelker-Orth Museum. Fee: $15; $10 for society members. Payment in advance. Reservations: (718) 939-0647.

''PRE-ROSH HASHANA SPECIAL: THE LOWER EAST SIDE'' looks at the changing immigrant population in the area. Sunday at 10 a.m. Fee: $15. Sponsored by the 92nd Street Y. Meeting place and reservations: (212) 996-1100.

''ANNUAL PRE-ROSH HASHANA TOUR: THE JEWISH LOWER EAST SIDE.'' Explores the historic settlements, once home to one of the largest Jewish communities in the world. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. at the southeast corner of Essex and Delancey Streets. Fee: $12; $10 for students and the elderly. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Information: (212) 439-1090.

''JACKSON HEIGHTS HISTORIC DISTRICT,'' Queens. Visits the area's 1920's garden apartments, commercial district and houses of worship. Meets Sunday at noon in front of the Community Church, at 82nd Street and 35th Avenue. Fee: $8. Sponsored by the Jackson Heights Beautification Group. Information: (212) 439-8784.

''JAZZ NIGHTS IN HARLEM.'' A tour of the area, with stops at the Apollo Theater and Theresa Hotel, followed by dinner and a stop at a jazz club. Meets tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 on the northeast corner of Lenox Avenue and 125th Street. Fee: $50. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Reservations: (212) 280-7888.

GREEN-WOOD CEMETERY. Brooklyn, a two-hour walk through the cemetery where Currier and Ives, Horace Greeley, Samuel F. B. Morse, Louis Comfort Tiffany, Leonard Bernstein and others are buried. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. inside the Fourth Avenue gate at 35th Street. Fee: $6. Led by John J. Cashman and Frank Mescall. Information: (718) 469-5277.

''THE FLYING AND THE FALLEN: AN ANGELIC TOUR'' celebrates All Angels and St. Michael's Day with a look at images of celestial beings. Meets Sunday at 1:30 p.m. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, Morningside Heights. Fee: $5. Sponsored by the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Binoculars are recommended. Reservations and information: (212) 932-7347.

''ROSH HASHANA RAMBLE,'' Lower East Side. Includes stops at the area's largest synagogue, a kosher winery, a pickle stand and a bialy bakery. Sunday at 11 a.m. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Fee: $5 (food additional). Meeting place and reservations (212) 265-2663.

''NOSH WALK IN SUNSET PARK,'' Brooklyn, includes stops at Asian, Turkish and Mexican markets and culminates with a picnic, weather permitting. Meets Sunday at 11 a.m. in the parking lot of Hong Kong Dynasty Supermarket, Eighth Avenue and 60th Street. Fee: $14; $16 day of tour. Sponsored by NoshWalks. Reservations and information: (212) 222-2243.

''PRE-ROSH HASHANA JEWISH LOWER EAST SIDE,'' Lower Manhattan. Meets Sunday at 2 P.M. inside Schapiro's Wine Cellars, 126 Rivington Street. Fee: $12, includes free kosher wine. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.
EVENTS

ARTS OF PACIFIC ASIA, 69th Street Regiment Armory, Lexington Avenue and 26th Street. An antiques and fine arts show. Today and tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Sunday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $15. Information: (212) 683-2434.

CRAFTS PARK AVENUE, Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street. Works by more than 100 artisans. Today, 3 to 8 p.m.; tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sunday, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $9; children under 16, free. Information: (800) 649-0279.

MANHATTAN SHORT FILM FESTIVAL, Union Square Park at 14th Street. Features the work of 14 aspiring filmmakers chosen from 512 contestants from around the world. Tonight at 8. Free. Web site: www.MSfilmfest.com. Information: (212) 613-5878.

METROPOLITAN VINTAGE FASHION AND ANTIQUE TEXTILE SHOW, Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street, Chelsea Today, noon to 7 p.m.; tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sunday, noon to 5 p.m. Admission, $20 today, $8 tomorrow and Sunday. Information: (212) 463-0200, extension 222.

''A JEWISH PLACE IN AMERICA,'' Eldridge Street Synagogue, 12 Eldridge Street, Lower East Side. Hasia Diner, an author and historian, will read from her book, ''Lower East Side Memories: A Jewish Place in America.'' Part of the Eldridge Street Project's Garden Cafeteria Literary Series. Sunday at 3 p.m. Admission: $6; students and seniors, $4. Information: (212) 978-8800.
